conclusion: To find the coefficient of kinetic friction \(\mu_k\) between objects A and B and the mass of A, we can examine the relationship between the force \(F\), acceleration \(a\), and friction.
Gravitational acceleration \(g = 10 \, \text{m/s}^2\). From the graph, the acceleration \(a\) is given as a linear function of force \(F\).
The force applied \(F\) causes an acceleration \(a\) on object A. The graph shows a linear relationship: \(a = \frac{F}{m} - \mu_k g\).
The graph shows the acceleration \(a\) as a function of \(F\).
The y-intercept of the graph represents the acceleration when \(F = 0\), which indicates the effect of friction alone.

premise: The y-intercept is \(-2 \, \text{m/s}^2\) from the graph. This value is due to the frictional force: \(-\mu_k g\).

conclusion: The slope of the graph represents the mass of object A.
From the graph, the slope is \( \frac{8}{60} = \frac{2}{15} \).
Thus, the mass of A is: \( m = \frac{2}{15} \, \text{kg}^{-1} \).

premise: Coefficient of kinetic friction \(\mu_k = 0.2\) and mass of A \(m = \frac{2}{15} \, \text{kg}^{-1}\).
conclusion: The coefficient of kinetic friction between A and B is \(0.2\). The mass of A is \(\frac{2}{15} \, \text{kg}^{-1}\).
